questions.text: The child presents with absent femoral pulses, increased blood pressure in the upper limbs, and dilated intercostal arteries. What is the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture is consistent with Coarctation of the Aorta (CoA), a congenital narrowing of the aortic lumen.
  • Classic triad: Hypertension in upper limbs, diminished/absent femoral pulses, and radial-femoral delay.
  • BP differential: Systolic BP in legs is lower than in arms (opposite of normal physiology).
  • Pulse findings: Femoral, dorsalis pedis, and posterior tibial pulses are absent or diminished in up to 40% of cases.
  • Collateral formation: Prominent in intercostal arteries, leading to rib notching visible on X-ray in older children.

Rib notching (marked with arrows)

  • Common in: Children >1 year with upper limb hypertension (>95th percentile).

Explanation of other options:

TOF (Option B): Cyanotic congenital heart disease with features like VSD, overriding aorta, RVH, and pulmonary stenosis. No femoral pulse delay.

PDA (Option C): Continuous "machinery" murmur and bounding pulses; doesn't cause upper-limb hypertension or femoral pulse delay.

Bicuspid Aortic Valve (Option D): May coexist with CoA but does not independently present with femoral pulse delay and upper-limb hypertension.

questions.text: A previously healthy term infant suddenly develops respiratory distress on day 3 of life. An echocardiogram reveals coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the immediate stabilisation of this infant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sudden deterioration in this neonate is due to the closure of the ductus arteriosus, unmasking a ductus-dependent lesion. In this case, coarctation of the aorta.

  • These lesions rely on the PDA to maintain systemic or pulmonary circulation.
  • As the PDA closes (usually between 24-72 hours post-birth), symptoms like shock, acidosis, and respiratory distress
  • Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1, alprostadil) is life-saving; it reopens or maintains ductal patency, restoring perfusion.
  • Once stabilised, definitive surgical correction is performed.

Explanation of other options:

Digoxin (Option A): Increases myocardial contractility, but is not helpful in ductus-dependent shock

Furosemide (Option B): Diuretic; not corrective for perfusion collapse due to duct closure

Racemic epinephrine (Option C): Used in croup and airway oedema; irrelevant here

Key Takeaways:

  • Always suspect a ductus-dependent cardiac lesion in any neonate who worsens around day 2-5 of life.
  • PGE1 is the first-line stabiliser
  • Definitive repair (e.g., resection of CoA) follows once the patient is hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: A child with congenital heart disease presents for evaluation. The chest X-ray image is shown below. Which of the following diagnosis-radiological matches is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows the "snowman heart" or "figure-of-eight sign" is a classic chest X-ray finding associated with Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC), specifically supracardiac type.
  • The upper "snowman head" is formed by a dilated vertical vein + SVC + left innominate vein.
  • The lower "snowman body" is due to an enlarged right atrium.
  • Seen best on frontal chest X-ray in older infants/children once pulmonary circulation increases.

questions.text: An infant presents with central cyanosis. On cardiac catheterisation, all four chambers of the heart are found to have identical oxygen saturation (SpO2) levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Equal oxygen saturation in all four chambers on catheterisation is diagnostic of TAPVC, a total mixing lesion.

  • In TAPVC, pulmonary veins do not connect to the left atrium, and instead drain into the right atrium, directly or indirectly.
  • This results in complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood at the atrial level.
  • Survival depends on the presence of an ASD or patent foramen ovale, which allows blood to cross into systemic circulation.

On investigation, oxygen saturation is identical in both atria, both ventricles and the aorta, a hallmark of TAPVC.

Explanation of other options:

TGA (Option A): Separate systemic and pulmonary circuits; saturations differ unless mixing

TOF (Option C): Right-to-left shunt via VSD; unequal saturations

Truncus Arteriosus (Option D): Common arterial trunk; left atrium still receives pulmonary venous return

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.text: A young female presents with a history of dyspnea on exertion. On examination, she has a wide, fixed split S2, with an ejection systolic murmur in the left second intercostal space. Her ECG shows left axis deviation. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of fixed splitting of S2 with left axis deviation on ECG is characteristic of Ostium Primum ASD.

  • Wide fixed split S2 indicates left-to-right atrial shunt, leading to delayed pulmonary valve closure.
  • Ejection systolic murmur over the pulmonary area reflects increased pulmonary blood flow.
  • Left axis deviation is a classic ECG finding in Ostium Primum ASD, due to abnormal conduction pathways associated with endocardial cushion defects.
  • This subtype is commonly associated with AV canal defects and Down syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Drainage (TAPVC) (Option A) usually presents in neonates or infants with central cyanosis, not isolated dyspnea or fixed S2. It is a mixing lesion and would not present with left axis deviation.

Tricuspid Atresia (Option B) is a cyanotic heart defect with a hypoplastic right ventricle. The ECG typically shows left ventricular dominance, but not a fixed S2 or a pulmonary flow murmur as seen in left-to-right shunts.

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) with Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (Option D) may present with a murmur and signs of pulmonary overflow but usually features a loud P2, not a fixed split S2. Additionally, left axis deviation is not typical of isolated VSD.

questions.text: The most common cardiac lesion in Down syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Endocardial cushion defect, also called atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD), is the most common cardiac lesion in Down syndrome.
  • Around 50% of children with Down syndrome have congenital heart disease.
  • AV canal defects are caused by failure of fusion of the endocardial cushions, leading to a combination of primum ASD, inlet VSD, and a common AV valve.
  • This defect is often complete in Down syndrome and predisposes to early congestive heart failure.

Syndromes vs Most Common Congenital Heart Defect (CHD)

Explanation of Other Options:

VSD (Option B): While VSDs are common in the general population, in Down syndrome, they are less frequent than complete AV canal defects.

Coarctation of the aorta (Option C): Rare in Down syndrome; more commonly associated with Turner syndrome.

TGA (Option D): Not a typical association with Down syndrome; usually presents in isolation.

questions.text: An angiographic image of a pediatric heart is shown below. Which of the following congenital heart diseases is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a typical goose-neck deformity.
  • Goose-neck deformity is characteristically seen in endocardial cushion defects due to elongation and narrowing of the left ventricular outflow tract.
  • This deformity is visualised on angiography as a lengthened, narrowed segment anterior to the mitral valve region and is highly suggestive of an atrioventricular septal defect.
  • It results from the anatomical distortion caused by the common AV valve and absence of the usual septal support. The associated atrial septal defect is typically of the ostium primum

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A): This presents with right ventricular hypertrophy and pulmonary stenosis but does not demonstrate a goose-neck configuration. The outflow tract is narrowed due to infundibular stenosis, not elongation.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (Option B): TAPVC involves abnormal venous drainage but has no effect on the morphology of the left ventricular outflow tract. No goose-neck appearance is seen.

Pulmonary Atresia (Option D): In this defect, the pulmonary valve is atretic or absent. The angiographic findings involve absent pulmonary flow, not elongation of the LVOT or goose-neck deformity.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Viridans group streptococci are the most frequent cause of infective endocarditis in pediatric patients, especially with pre-existing heart disease.

  • Viridans-type streptococci (e.g., Streptococcus mitis, S. sanguinis, S. mutans) are α-hemolytic streptococci and dominate endocarditis cases in children with congenital or rheumatic heart disease.
  • These organisms are low virulence but can adhere to damaged valves and initiate subacute infective endocarditis.

Explanation of other options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A) is more common in acute endocarditis, especially in IV drug users or catheter-related infections. It causes rapidly progressive disease, but it is less common in children with underlying heart defects.

HACEK organisms (Option B) are a rare cause in pediatric cases. Though they can cause culture-negative endocarditis, they are more commonly implicated in adults.

Klebsiella (Option D ) is an unusual cause of endocarditis and is typically seen in immunocompromised or nosocomial settings. It is not considered a typical pathogen in community-acquired pediatric cases.

choices.text: Infective endocarditis prophylaxis needs to continue lifelong despite surgery

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with TOF. He underwent a successful surgical complete repair. After how much time after surgery can the prophylaxis of infective endocarditis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to the latest guidelines,lifelong IE prophylaxis is not needed in most patients.
  • The prophylaxis is recommended inuncorrected disorders, especially cyanotic diseases like TOF and then for 6 months after successful surgical repair.
  • After that, IE prophylaxis can be safely stopped.

Conditions where antibiotic prophylaxis is needed against IE

  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Past history of IE
  • Uncorrected cyanotic heart disease, palliative shunts and conduits
  • During 1st 6 monthsfollowing complete surgical repair of CHDs
  • Repaired CHDs withresidual defects at or adjacent to the site of repair
  • Cardiac transplantationrecipients with cardiac valvulopathy

Explanation of other options:

Immediately after surgery (Option A): Prophylaxis is not discontinued immediately after surgery, as the risk of infective endocarditis remains during the healing and endothelialisation phase.

After 12 months of surgery (Option C): Waiting for 12 months is unnecessary according to the latest guidelines if healing is complete and no prosthetic material is exposed.

Infective endocarditis prophylaxis needs to continue lifelong despite surgery (Option D): Lifelong prophylaxis is reserved for patients with high-risk conditions like prosthetic valves, not for successfully corrected TOF.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child has Acute Rheumatic Fever and has no cardiac manifestations. What should be the duration of antibiotic prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The current age of the patient is 11 years. For rheumatic fever without any cardiac manifestations, penicillin prophylaxis is given for 5 years or till 21 years of age, whichever is longer. since the patient age is 11 years(21-11 = 10 years).
  • 10 years is longer than 5yrs.

Prophylaxis of ARF

  1. Primary: Penicillin G given before the 9th day of symptoms of strep sore throat
  2. Secondary: DOC - Benzathine PnG: 1.2 million units IM for 21 days. If Pn is allergic, then give macrolides, Eg, Erythromycin/Sulfadiazine or sulfisoxazole

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF). He presents with migratory polyarthritis, tachycardia disproportionate to fever, and a newly detected pansystolic murmur. Which of the following should be the preferred anti-inflammatory drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child has rheumatic carditis (suggested by murmur + disproportionate tachycardia), which requires steroid therapy for controlling myocardial inflammation.

  • Carditis with or without CCF: Steroids preferred over Aspirin
  • Anti-inflammatory therapy in ARF reduces acute inflammation and prevents valve damage
  • NSAIDs (like Aspirin) are reserved for isolated arthritis without cardiac involvement
  • Dose of Steroids: Prednisolone 2 mg/kg for 3 weeks, then tapered over 9 weeks; total duration is 12 weeks.
  • Dose of Aspirin: 90-120 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses for 10 weeks, then tapered over 2 weeks; total duration is 12 weeks.

Explanation of other options:

Benzathine Penicillin G (Option A): Indicated for the eradication of streptococcus and secondary prophylaxis, not inflammation suppression.

Aspirin (Option B): Used only when carditis is absent; not first-line in this case.

Furosemide (Option D): Symptomatic treatment in heart failure, not disease-modifying for rheumatic inflammation.

questions.text: Medical closure of PDA is contraindicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Medical closure of PDA is contraindicated when the platelet count is below 80,000/mm³ due to the increased risk of bleeding with NSAID therapy.
  • Indomethacin or ibuprofen, used for PDA closure, can exacerbate bleeding tendencies; hence, thrombocytopenia is an absolute contraindication.

Contraindications for medical closure of PDA

  • Platelet count < 80000/mm3
  • AKI or Sr. creatinine>1.8mg/dl. (Option B ruled out)
  • NEC/Feed in tolerance
  • Unexplained bleeding.

Explanation of other options:

Large PDA with bounding pulses (Option C): This is an indication, not a contraindication, for closure due to a significant left-to-right shunt.

Low birth weight (Option D): Not a direct contraindication, although extreme prematurity may require supportive management before closure.

questions.text: A child with PDA will not have which among the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Children with PDA develop pulmonary congestion due to increased pulmonary blood flow, which results in CO2 retention, not CO2 washout.
  • PDA causes a left-to-right shunt, which causes pulmonary overcirculation, leading to pulmonary oedema and congestion.
  • This leads to impaired gas exchange and CO2 retention, not increased clearance.

Explanation of other options:

Bounding pulses (Option A): Seen in PDA due to wide pulse pressure. Mechanism: Diastolic runoff of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery decreases diastolic BP, producing bounding peripheral pulses.

Pulmonary haemorrhage (Option B): May occur due to pulmonary overcirculation and capillary stress in preterm infants.

Necrotising enterocolitis (Option C): PDA-related systemic hypoperfusion and diastolic steal phenomenon can predispose to NEC.

questions.text: A child with cyanotic heart disease was found to have SVT & evaluation revealed Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome. Which disease might it have been?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ebstein's anomaly is the most common cyanotic CHD associated with supraventricular arrhythmias, especially WPW syndrome.
  • The downward displacement of the tricuspid valve causes atrialization of the right ventricle, predisposing to accessory pathway conduction and re-entrant tachyarrhythmias.
  • It is also associated with maternal lithium exposure and pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Pansystolic murmur is present
  • Rx: TV valve replacement.

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A): Presents with cyanotic spells due to RV outflow obstruction, but WPW syndrome and SVT are not characteristic.

Tricuspid Atresia (Option C): Cyanotic CHD with obligatory right-to-left shunt, but it typically causes bradycardia or AV block risk rather than WPW.

TGA (Option D): Causes cyanosis and heart failure in infancy; arrhythmias are not a common presenting feature before surgery.

questions.text: A 5-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth. Prostaglandin E was administered initially, and later, balloon atrial septostomy was done, which showed improvement in oxygenation. What is the most likely diagnosis of this infant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cyanosis at birth, PGE infusion and atrial septostomy to improve oxygen are typical of TGA.

  • Incomplete transposition of great vessels, there are independent systemic and pulmonary circulations with communication only through the ductus arteriosus.
  • Hence, patency of the ductus arteriosus is to be maintained to ensure mixing of blood.
  • Due to deoxygenated blood flowing in the systemic circulation, moderate to severe cyanosis is present at birth.
  • As a part of rescue therapy initially, Rashkind's atrial septostomy is done to ensure mixing of blood,followed by definitive

Explanation of other options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A): Cyanosis is often delayed in mild cases and improves with squatting; PGE and atrial septostomy are usually not required initially.

Truncus Arteriosus (Option C): Presents with cyanosis and CHF, but PGE is not critical because systemic and pulmonary circulation are already mixed.

Tricuspid Atresia (Option D): Cyanosis occurs due to limited pulmonary flow, but atrial septostomy is not the primary intervention unless ASD is restrictive.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart diseases would be expected to exhibit cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TGA with VSDis the most common cause of cyanosis in the first week of life.
  • In TGA, systemic and pulmonary circulations are parallel, resulting in minimal oxygenated blood reaching the systemic circulation.
  • Cyanosis appears immediately after birth and worsens as the ductus arteriosus begins to close.
  • The presence of a VSD or PDA is critical for the mixing of blood; without it, survival is compromised.

Explanation of other options:

TOF in 2-year-old (Option A): Cyanosis may appear later; early neonatal cyanosis is uncommon unless severe RVOT obstruction exists.

Large PDA with distal narrowing (Option C): PDA causes left-to-right shunt, which leads to pulmonary overcirculation, not early cyanosis.

Supracristal VSD in a 4-month-old (Option D): Primarily a left-to-right shunt lesion, cyanosis only occurs late if Eisenmenger physiology develops.

questions.text: A full-term infant develops cyanosis, tachypnea, and a sharp drop in oxygen saturation within the first 30 minutes of birth. On examination, she has normal heart sounds, normal liver edge, and oxygen saturation in the low 60s. When placed on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and 100% oxygen, her oxygen saturation remains in the low 70s. A chest X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Egg-on-string appearance in a cyanotic neonate unresponsive to 100% O2 strongly suggests
  • In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, creating parallel circulations.
  • Deoxygenated systemic blood recirculates to the body → severe cyanosis in the first hours of life.
  • Mixing through PDA, ASD, or VSD is essential for survival.

Acute Management:

  • Prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent
  • Balloon atrial septostomy (Rashkind procedure) to improve atrial-level mixing
  • Definitive treatment: Early arterial switch (Jatene) surgery

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary atresia (Option A): Cyanosis occurs, but CXR often shows oligemic lungs, not a narrow mediastinum.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C): Cyanosis usually develops later; CXR shows a boot-shaped heart, not egg-on-string.

Hypoplastic left heart (Option D): CXR shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary oedema, not an isolated narrow mediastinum.

choices.text: Maximum intensity at the left lower sternal border.

questions.text: Which one of the following murmur characteristics supports the diagnosis of an innocent murmur?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Innocent murmurs are typically soft, short, and vary with posture or respiration.
  • The most common innocent murmur is a medium-pitched, vibratory or "musical" systolic ejection murmur, heard best along the left lower to mid-sternal border.
  • Key feature: Intensity changes with respiration and posture and attenuates when sitting or prone.
  • No significant radiation or associated thrill is present.
  • Most commonly heard in children aged 3-7 years and often disappear with age.

Explanation of other options:

Palpable thrill (Option A): Presence of a thrill suggests pathologic murmur, often associated with structural CHD (like VSD or AS).

Radiation to neck (Option C): Characteristic of aortic stenosis, a pathological murmur.

Max intensity at LLSB (Option D): Alone, this is not diagnostic; some pathologic murmurs can also present here.

questions.text: A 4-day-old infant presents with decreased oral intake and activity. His birth history is unremarkable, and he was discharged home on day 2 of his life. On examination, the child is cool, mottled, with decreased pulses. No murmur. Which is the most likely congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is classic for ductus-dependent systemic circulation failure, especially Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS).

  • Neonatal shock in 1st week suggests closure of the ductus arteriosus in duct-dependent lesions.
  • In HLHS, systemic output is maintained by PDA; its closure leads to cardiogenic shock.
  • Clinical clues: Greyish pallor, poor perfusion, weak peripheral pulses, and absence of prominent murmur.
  • Most HLHS infants present in the first week of life with right-sided and left-sided heart failure.
  • Murmurs are often absent or faint; a soft mid-systolic or mid-diastolic murmur may be heard occasionally.

Explanation of other options:

Transposition of Great Vessels (TGA) (Option A): Presents with early cyanosis, not shock. PDA helps with oxygen mixing but not systemic output.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (Option B): Cyanotic defect; typically presents with murmur and hypoxic spells rather than shock in the first week.

Ebstein's Anomaly (Option C): Cyanotic lesion with tricuspid valve abnormality, not classically associated with ductus-dependent systemic failure.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl with Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collaterals presents with slurred speech and facial droop, suggestive of a cerebrovascular accident.
She has undergone multiple palliative cardiac surgeries and is under palliative care with no further interventions planned.
Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polycythemia is the primary risk factor for cerebrovascular events in patients with longstanding cyanotic congenital heart disease.
  • Chronic hypoxemia stimulates erythropoietin production, leading to secondary polycythemia.
  • Increased hematocrit causes hyperviscosity, which predisposes to cerebral thrombosis or stroke, especially in older children with unrepaired or palliated TOF.
  • Careful monitoring of hematocrit and hydration is critical to prevent hyperviscosity complications.

Explanation of other options:

Heart failure (Option A): TOF with pulmonary atresia rarely presents with classic heart failure in adolescence unless there is severe RV dysfunction.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option B): Can worsen cyanosis due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity, but does not directly predispose to stroke.

Pulmonary overcirculation (Option D): Seen in left-to-right shunts (like VSD, PDA), not in severe TOF with pulmonary atresia

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy arrives in the emergency room with tachypnea and retractions. His mother reports he has nasal congestion, cough, and is not able to feed well. On auscultation, you note fine basal crackles. His HR is 190, and a 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur is identified along the left sternal border. He also has hepatomegaly. CXR shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Which medication is indicated for symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This 3-month-old infant presents with tachypnea, retractions, hepatomegaly, murmur, and increased pulmonary vascular markings, which are classic signs of congestive heart failure (CCF) due to a large left-to-right shunt (e.g., VSD).
  • Furosemide is the drug of choice for symptomatic relief as it reduces preload and pulmonary congestion.

Cyanotic vs Acyanotic CHDs by Lung Fields

Explanation of other options:

Inhaled Salbutamol (Option A): Bronchodilator used for bronchospasm, not heart failure

Racemic Epinephrine (Option B): For airway oedema (e.g., croup), not applicable here

Indomethacin (Option C): Used to close PDA in preterm infants, contraindicated in CCF

questions.text:
NADAS' minor criteria for congenital heart disease include which of the following?
1. Abnormal S2
2. Systolic Murmur grade 2/6
3. Diastolic Murmur
4. Low BP
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abnormal S2, soft systolic murmurs, and low BP are all considered minor findings under the NADAS criteria.

  • NADAS Criteria are used to screen children for possible congenital heart disease and are divided into major and minor
  • Minor criteria include:
    • Abnormal second heart sound (S2)
    • Systolic murmur Grade 2/6 or less
    • Low blood pressure for age
  • These findings are less specific but warrant further cardiac evaluation when present together or with any major signs.
  • Diastolic murmurs are classified under major NADAS criteria, not minor.
    Any diastolic murmur is pathologic and thus significant enough to be labelled a major finding, not minor.

NADAS Criteria Table

questions.text:
Increased pulmonary blood flow is seen in?
1. TOF
2. Ebstein's Anomaly
3. TGA
4. Tricuspid Atresia
5. TAPVC
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital Heart Diseases Based Upon Pulmonary Blood Flow

  • Increased pulmonary blood flow
    • Allleft-to-right lesions like ASD, VSD, PDA, ECD, etc
    • TGA
    • TAPVC
    • Truncus Arteriosus
  • Reduced pulmonary blood flow
    • TOF
    • Tricuspid Atresia
    • Ebstein's Anomaly
    • Pulmonary Atresia
    • Eisenmenger Syndrome
  • All conditions withincreased pulmonary blood flow will show pulmonary plethora on CXR due to increased vascular markings, while all conditions with reduced pulmonary blood flow will have pulmonary oligemia on CXR due to reduced vascular markings.

questions.text: Most consistent sign of infantile CCF?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is best supported by hepatomegaly, which is the most consistent clinical sign of CCF in infants due to their highly compliant vascular systems and immature renal function.
  • Hepatomegaly occurs due to hepatic venous congestion and is reliably detected on physical exam.
  • Pedal oedema is less frequently observed in infants compared to older children or adults. (Option B ruled out)

Basal crepitations and elevated JVP are variable and less reliable indicators in early infancy. (Options A and D ruled out)

questions.text: The Least risk of CCF is seen in which of the following heart diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TOF rarely leads to CCF because the large VSD decompresses the right ventricle via a right-to-left shunt into the overriding aorta.
  • This effective decompression prevents significant right-sided volume overload, which is the primary mechanism of CCF. As a result, cyanotic spells are more common than heart failure in TOF patients.

Explanation of other options:

ASD (Option A): Over time, especially with large defects, left-to-right shunting leads to right heart volume overload, predisposing to CCF in infancy if pulmonary vascular resistance drops.

VSD (Option B): Moderate-to-large VSDs with significant left-to-right shunt often present with early CCF in infants due to pulmonary overcirculation.

TGA (Option D): Without early intervention, TGA causes pulmonary overcirculation and heart failure due to parallel circulations requiring shunt-dependent mixing.
